title: Interest rate tweaks to pay for new drought loans
text:
New concessional loans for farmers struggling with the drought could be funded by increasing the interest rates on other low-cost loans for farmers to keep pressure off the budget.

The decision on how to absorb the cost of the new loans will be made in about six months by the Regional Investment Corporation, a body known colloquially as the "Barnaby Bank" which was established by the government last term to distribute drought assistance.

Scott Morrison and Drought Minister David Littleproud. Alex Ellinghausen

As part of its rolling response to the drought, the government recently announced new loans to help farmers affected by drought to restock and replant.

The loans are for a maximum of $200,000. They are interest-free for the first two years, interest-only for the next three years, and attract concessional rates for the five years after that.

The loans are in addition to standard drought loans administered by the RIC for amounts up to $2 million. They attract the concessional interest rate of 3.1 per cent, which is the bond rate plus a margin to cover administration and other costs.
